cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
What city celebrates the original Oktoberfest?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: Oktoberfest is a traditional beer festival that originated in Germany. The original Oktoberfest began in 1810 in Munich, where it was held to celebrate the marriage of Crown Prince Ludwig to Princess Therese of Saxe-Hildburghausen. Over the years, it evolved into a large annual festival featuring beer, food, and various attractions. Therefore, the city that celebrates the original Oktoberfest is Munich.

Answer: Munich

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
What city celebrates the original Oktoberfest?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Delaware Sängerbund Oktoberfest is named after the widely known festival held each year in Munich, Bavaria. There, the first Oktoberfest was celebrated as a wedding festival of the Bavarian crown prince Ludwig on October 12, 1810. In later years, the festival commemorating the wedding grew larger and longer, first in the city, then countrywide. To ensure milder weather for all the outdoor activities, the beginning of the sixteen-day-long celebrations was moved into September, only the last weekend falling into October. The name "Oktoberfest" remained with the fair.\n', 'BULLET::::- Frankenmuth, Michigan (The first Oktoberfest outside Munich that the Parliament and the City of Munich sanctioned);\n', 'The Oktoberfest is a two-week festival held each year in Munich, Germany during late September and early October. It is attended by six million people each year and has inspired numerous similar events using the name "Oktoberfest" in Germany and around the world, many of which were founded by German immigrants or their descendants.\n', 'Oktoberfest () is the world\'s largest Volksfest (beer festival and travelling funfair). Held annually in Munich, Bavaria, Germany, it is a 16- to 18-day folk festival running from mid or late September to the first weekend in October, with more than six million people from around the world attending the event every year. Locally, it is often called the Wiesn, after the colloquial name for the fairgrounds, Theresa\'s meadows ("Theresienwiese"). The Oktoberfest is an important part of Bavarian culture, having been held since the year 1810. Other cities across the world also hold Oktoberfest celebrations that are modeled after the original Munich event.\n', '"September and October, Theresienwiese": The largest beer festival in the world, Munich\'s Oktoberfest runs for 16–18 days from the end of September through early October. Oktoberfest is a celebration of the wedding of Bavarian Crown Prince Ludwig to Princess Therese of Saxony-Hildburghausen which took place on October 12, 1810. In the last 200 years the festival has grown to span 85 acres and now welcomes over 6 million visitors every year. There are 14 beer tents which together can seat 119,000 attendees at a time, and serve beer from the six major breweries of Munich: Augustiner, Hacker-Pschorr, Löwenbräu, Paulaner, Spaten and Staatliches Hofbräuhaus. Over 7 million liters of beer are consumed at each Oktoberfest. There are also over 100 rides ranging from bumper cars to full-sized roller coasters, as well as the more traditional Ferris wheels and swings. Food can be bought in each tent, as well as at various stalls throughout the fairgrounds. Oktoberfest hosts 144 caterers and employees 13,000 people.\n', 'The Oktoberfest of Blumenau was created in 1984, after a big flood of the Itajaí-Açu river, with the objective of recuperating the city\'s economy and raising the morale of its inhabitants. Even before that, owners of industries and commercial buildings in the city were already planning to start a festival like the original fromm Munich, but the flood was an important event that set the festival in motion. Since its first edition it has been a success, and today it has an attendance of about than 700,000/year. The event features folk dance ("Tanzgruppen)", shooting matches ("Schützenvereine"), German singing, folk costume and german cuisine. "Fritz" and "Frida" are the typical German characters. The ""Vovó e Vovô Chopão"" (Grandma and Grandpa "Chopão", "Big Beer") are the official symbolic characters of the event.\n', 'On the occasion of the 200th anniversary in 2010 a so-called "Historisches Oktoberfest" (Historical Oktoberfest) was designed on the site of the Central Agricultural Festival at the south end of the "Theresienwiese". It opened one day before the official Oktoberfest with the traditional keg tapping by the Lord Mayor.\n', 'Maifest, similar to Oktoberfest, has now become a popular celebration throughout the world. It has been celebrated in Cincinnati, Ohio, United States since 1873.\n', 'Oktoberfest Zinzinnati is an annual weekend festival in the city of Cincinnati, Ohio. Based on the original German Oktoberfest, it is billed as the largest Oktoberfest celebration in the United States. First held in 1976, it attracts an estimated 500,000 visitors every year in late September. It is held along six blocks of Downtown Cincinnati. As of 2016, Oktoberfest is held on 3rd Street to clear room for Cincinnati Streetcar operations.\n', 'Oktoberfest is an outdoor beer festival held during a 16-day period running from late September to the first weekend in October, celebrating beer in Munich, Germany.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question about which city celebrates the original Oktoberfest, we can extract and analyze several key pieces of information from the provided passages. This will help clarify the historical and cultural significance of Oktoberfest, as well as its origins.

### Extracted Content:

1. **Origin of Oktoberfest**:
   - The first Oktoberfest was celebrated in Munich, Bavaria, as a wedding festival for Bavarian Crown Prince Ludwig on October 12, 1810. This historical context is crucial as it establishes Munich as the birthplace of the festival.

2. **Evolution of the Festival**:
   - The festival began as a wedding celebration and gradually grew larger and longer over the years. This indicates that Oktoberfest has deep cultural roots and has evolved significantly since its inception.

3. **Timing and Duration**:
   - Oktoberfest is now a two-week festival held annually in Munich, Germany, during late September and early October. The festival has been adjusted to start in September to ensure milder weather, with only the last weekend falling into October. This detail highlights the logistical considerations that have shaped the festival's current format.

4. **Cultural Significance**:
   - The festival is described as the world's largest Volksfest (beer festival and traveling funfair), attracting over six million visitors each year. This emphasizes the scale and importance of Oktoberfest not just locally, but globally.

5. **Local Name**:
   - Locally, Oktoberfest is often referred to as "Wiesn," named after the fairgrounds (Theresienwiese) where it takes place. This local nomenclature adds to the cultural identity of the festival.

6. **Beer Consumption and Festivities**:
   - The festival features 14 beer tents, serves beer from six major Munich breweries, and involves significant beer consumption (over 7 million liters annually). This information underscores the festival's focus on beer culture and communal celebration.

7. **Global Influence**:
   - The passages mention that many cities around the world hold Oktoberfest celebrations modeled after the original in Munich, indicating the festival's influence and the spread of Bavarian culture internationally.

### Analysis of the Role of Extracted Content:

- **Historical Context**: Understanding the origins of Oktoberfest in Munich provides a foundational knowledge that is essential for answering the question. It situates the festival within a specific historical event (a royal wedding), which adds depth to its significance.

- **Cultural Significance**: The details about the festival's scale, local customs, and the communal aspect of beer consumption highlight why Oktoberfest is not just a local event but a cultural phenomenon that resonates with people worldwide.

- **Logistical Details**: Information about the timing and duration of the festival helps clarify how the event has adapted over time, which is important for understanding its current form.

- **Global Influence**: Recognizing that Oktoberfest has inspired similar celebrations worldwide illustrates its impact beyond Munich, reinforcing the idea that while many cities celebrate Oktoberfest, the original event remains uniquely tied to Munich.

### Conclusion:

The city that celebrates the original Oktoberfest is Munich, Bavaria, Germany. The extracted content provides a comprehensive understanding of the festival's origins, cultural significance, and global influence, which enriches the model's ability to respond to the question accurately and contextually.

To determine which city celebrates the original Oktoberfest, we can analyze the historical and cultural context surrounding this festival. 

1. **Historical Origin**: The original Oktoberfest was first celebrated in Munich, Bavaria, on October 12, 1810. It was organized to commemorate the marriage of Crown Prince Ludwig to Princess Therese of Saxe-Hildburghausen. This historical event is pivotal as it marks the inception of the festival.

2. **Evolution Over Time**: Initially a wedding celebration, Oktoberfest has grown significantly over the years, evolving into a large-scale annual festival that attracts millions. This transformation highlights the festival's deep cultural roots and its importance in Bavarian tradition.

3. **Timing and Duration**: Oktoberfest is now held annually in Munich, typically spanning two weeks from late September to the first weekend in October. The festival was adjusted to start in September to take advantage of milder weather, with only the last weekend falling in October. This logistical detail is essential for understanding the festival's current format and its seasonal significance.

4. **Cultural Significance**: Recognized as the world's largest Volksfest (beer festival and traveling funfair), Oktoberfest attracts over six million visitors each year. This statistic underscores its global importance and the communal spirit it fosters among attendees.

5. **Local Terminology**: The festival is often referred to as "Wiesn," named after the fairgrounds (Theresienwiese) where it takes place. This local name adds to the cultural identity of the festival and connects it to the specific location in Munich.

6. **Beer Culture and Festivities**: Oktoberfest features 14 beer tents, serves beer from six major Munich breweries, and sees over seven million liters of beer consumed annually. This emphasis on beer culture is central to the festival's identity and reflects Bavarian traditions.

7. **Global Influence**: The passages indicate that many cities worldwide hold Oktoberfest celebrations modeled after the original in Munich. This highlights the festival's influence and the spread of Bavarian culture beyond its origins.

### Conclusion:
The city that celebrates the original Oktoberfest is Munich, Bavaria, Germany. This conclusion is supported by the historical context of the festival's origins, its evolution into a significant cultural event, and its global influence. The extracted knowledge enhances our understanding of why Munich is not just the birthplace of Oktoberfest but also its enduring cultural heart.

Answer:
Munich, Bavaria, Germany.

The original Oktoberfest is a renowned beer festival that takes place annually in Munich, Bavaria, Germany. It began in 1810 as a royal wedding celebration for Bavarian Crown Prince Ludwig and Princess Therese of Saxony-Hildburghausen. This historical context is crucial, as it highlights the festival's roots in Bavarian culture and its significance as a communal celebration.

Over the years, Oktoberfest has transformed from a one-day event into a massive festival lasting 16 to 18 days, typically starting in late September and concluding in early October. This adjustment in timing was made to take advantage of milder weather for outdoor festivities, although the name "Oktoberfest" has remained unchanged.

Key aspects of Oktoberfest include:

1. **Cultural Significance**: Oktoberfest is not only the largest beer festival in the world but also a vital expression of Bavarian culture, featuring traditional foods, music, and folk customs. This cultural aspect enhances the understanding of why the festival is celebrated with such enthusiasm.

2. **Global Influence**: The success of the Munich Oktoberfest has inspired similar celebrations around the world, particularly in cities with significant German immigrant communities, such as Cincinnati, Ohio. This global reach illustrates the festival's impact beyond its origins.

3. **Scale and Attendance**: With over six million visitors each year, Oktoberfest features numerous beer tents, rides, and food stalls, showcasing its massive scale and popularity. This attendance figure underscores the festival's importance as a major tourist attraction.

4. **Local Terminology**: The festival is often referred to as "Wiesn," named after the fairgrounds (Theresienwiese) where it is held. This local terminology reflects the festival's deep-rooted connection to the city of Munich.

By synthesizing this information, we can appreciate Oktoberfest not just as a local event but as a significant cultural phenomenon that celebrates Bavarian heritage and fosters community spirit. This understanding emphasizes Munich's pivotal role in the festival's history and ongoing legacy, reinforcing that the city is indeed the birthplace and home of the original Oktoberfest.

**Answer:**
Munich

1. **Origin of Oktoberfest**: The original Oktoberfest was celebrated in Munich, Bavaria, as a wedding festival for Bavarian Crown Prince Ludwig and Princess Therese of Saxony-Hildburghausen on October 12, 1810.

2. **Evolution of the Festival**: The festival started as a one-day event and grew larger over the years, eventually becoming a two-week celebration held annually in Munich. The timing was adjusted to begin in late September to ensure milder weather, although the name "Oktoberfest" remained.

3. **Cultural Significance**: Oktoberfest is recognized as the world's largest Volksfest (beer festival and traveling funfair), attracting over six million visitors each year. It has become an important part of Bavarian culture and has inspired similar events worldwide.

4. **Scale and Features**: The festival spans 16 to 18 days, features numerous beer tents, rides, and food stalls, and serves beer from major Munich breweries. It has grown to accommodate a vast number of attendees and has a significant economic impact.

5. **Global Influence**: Numerous cities around the world have adopted the name "Oktoberfest" for their own celebrations, often modeled after the original event in Munich, indicating the festival's cultural export and influence.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference

1. **Understanding Causality**: The information about the origins of Oktoberfest allows the model to understand the causal relationship between historical events (the royal wedding) and the establishment of a cultural festival. This can enhance the model's ability to infer how specific events lead to broader cultural phenomena.

2. **Temporal Reasoning**: The evolution of the festival over time, including changes in duration and timing, provides a basis for the model to reason about how and why events change in response to environmental factors (e.g., weather). This temporal aspect can improve the model's ability to make inferences about the timing and duration of events in other contexts.

3. **Cultural Significance and Influence**: The passages highlight the cultural significance of Oktoberfest and its global influence, which can help the model understand how local traditions can spread and evolve into international phenomena. This understanding can enhance the model's reasoning about cultural diffusion and adaptation.

4. **Scale and Economic Impact**: The details about the scale of the festival and its economic implications can help the model infer relationships between large events and their effects on local economies. This can improve the model's ability to analyze economic causality in various scenarios.

5. **Comparative Analysis**: By noting that many cities have their own Oktoberfest celebrations, the model can learn to compare and contrast different events, understanding how they may be similar or different based on their origins, cultural contexts, and local adaptations.

In summary, the extracted information provides a rich context for enhancing the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities by illustrating the relationships between historical events, cultural evolution, and economic impact. This can lead to improved reasoning about similar phenomena in various domains.

What city celebrates the original Oktoberfest?

Passages:
['The Delaware Sängerbund Oktoberfest is named after the widely known festival held each year in Munich, Bavaria. There, the first Oktoberfest was celebrated as a wedding festival of the Bavarian crown prince Ludwig on October 12, 1810. In later years, the festival commemorating the wedding grew larger and longer, first in the city, then countrywide. To ensure milder weather for all the outdoor activities, the beginning of the sixteen-day-long celebrations was moved into September, only the last weekend falling into October. The name "Oktoberfest" remained with the fair.\n', 'BULLET::::- Frankenmuth, Michigan (The first Oktoberfest outside Munich that the Parliament and the City of Munich sanctioned);\n', 'The Oktoberfest is a two-week festival held each year in Munich, Germany during late September and early October. It is attended by six million people each year and has inspired numerous similar events using the name "Oktoberfest" in Germany and around the world, many of which were founded by German immigrants or their descendants.\n', 'Oktoberfest () is the world\'s largest Volksfest (beer festival and travelling funfair). Held annually in Munich, Bavaria, Germany, it is a 16- to 18-day folk festival running from mid or late September to the first weekend in October, with more than six million people from around the world attending the event every year. Locally, it is often called the Wiesn, after the colloquial name for the fairgrounds, Theresa\'s meadows ("Theresienwiese"). The Oktoberfest is an important part of Bavarian culture, having been held since the year 1810. Other cities across the world also hold Oktoberfest celebrations that are modeled after the original Munich event.\n', '"September and October, Theresienwiese": The largest beer festival in the world, Munich\'s Oktoberfest runs for 16–18 days from the end of September through early October. Oktoberfest is a celebration of the wedding of Bavarian Crown Prince Ludwig to Princess Therese of Saxony-Hildburghausen which took place on October 12, 1810. In the last 200 years the festival has grown to span 85 acres and now welcomes over 6 million visitors every year. There are 14 beer tents which together can seat 119,000 attendees at a time, and serve beer from the six major breweries of Munich: Augustiner, Hacker-Pschorr, Löwenbräu, Paulaner, Spaten and Staatliches Hofbräuhaus. Over 7 million liters of beer are consumed at each Oktoberfest. There are also over 100 rides ranging from bumper cars to full-sized roller coasters, as well as the more traditional Ferris wheels and swings. Food can be bought in each tent, as well as at various stalls throughout the fairgrounds. Oktoberfest hosts 144 caterers and employees 13,000 people.\n', 'The Oktoberfest of Blumenau was created in 1984, after a big flood of the Itajaí-Açu river, with the objective of recuperating the city\'s economy and raising the morale of its inhabitants. Even before that, owners of industries and commercial buildings in the city were already planning to start a festival like the original fromm Munich, but the flood was an important event that set the festival in motion. Since its first edition it has been a success, and today it has an attendance of about than 700,000/year. The event features folk dance ("Tanzgruppen)", shooting matches ("Schützenvereine"), German singing, folk costume and german cuisine. "Fritz" and "Frida" are the typical German characters. The ""Vovó e Vovô Chopão"" (Grandma and Grandpa "Chopão", "Big Beer") are the official symbolic characters of the event.\n', 'On the occasion of the 200th anniversary in 2010 a so-called "Historisches Oktoberfest" (Historical Oktoberfest) was designed on the site of the Central Agricultural Festival at the south end of the "Theresienwiese". It opened one day before the official Oktoberfest with the traditional keg tapping by the Lord Mayor.\n', 'Maifest, similar to Oktoberfest, has now become a popular celebration throughout the world. It has been celebrated in Cincinnati, Ohio, United States since 1873.\n', 'Oktoberfest Zinzinnati is an annual weekend festival in the city of Cincinnati, Ohio. Based on the original German Oktoberfest, it is billed as the largest Oktoberfest celebration in the United States. First held in 1976, it attracts an estimated 500,000 visitors every year in late September. It is held along six blocks of Downtown Cincinnati. As of 2016, Oktoberfest is held on 3rd Street to clear room for Cincinnati Streetcar operations.\n', 'Oktoberfest is an outdoor beer festival held during a 16-day period running from late September to the first weekend in October, celebrating beer in Munich, Germany.\n']

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

Oktoberfest is a traditional beer festival that originated in Germany. The original Oktoberfest began in 1810 in Munich, where it was held to celebrate the marriage of Crown Prince Ludwig to Princess Therese of Saxe-Hildburghausen on October 12, 1810. This historical context is crucial as it highlights the festival's origins and significance in Bavarian culture.

The festival has evolved over the years into a large annual event that lasts 16 to 18 days, typically running from late September to the first weekend in October. This timing is essential for understanding when the festival occurs and its duration, which attracts over six million visitors each year.

The scale of Oktoberfest is noteworthy, as it serves over seven million liters of beer and features various attractions, food, and entertainment. This quantitative aspect emphasizes the festival's massive popularity and cultural importance.

Furthermore, the influence of Oktoberfest extends beyond Munich, as many cities around the world now hold their own Oktoberfest celebrations modeled after the original event. This global reach illustrates the festival's impact and the way it has been embraced by communities outside of Germany.

In 2010, the "Historisches Oktoberfest" was held to celebrate the 200th anniversary of the original festival, providing additional historical context that showcases the festival's long-standing tradition and evolution over time.

By incorporating these details, the model can enhance its understanding of Oktoberfest, ensuring that it accurately reflects the festival's origins, significance, scale, and global influence.

**Answer:**
Munich

question_info.question: What city celebrates the original Oktoberfest?
passages:
The Delaware Sängerbund Oktoberfest is named after the widely known festival held each year in Munich, Bavaria. There, the first Oktoberfest was celebrated as a wedding festival of the Bavarian crown prince Ludwig on October 12, 1810. In later years, the festival commemorating the wedding grew larger and longer, first in the city, then countrywide. To ensure milder weather for all the outdoor activities, the beginning of the sixteen-day-long celebrations was moved into September, only the last weekend falling into October. The name "Oktoberfest" remained with the fair.
BULLET::::- Frankenmuth, Michigan (The first Oktoberfest outside Munich that the Parliament and the City of Munich sanctioned);
The Oktoberfest is a two-week festival held each year in Munich, Germany during late September and early October. It is attended by six million people each year and has inspired numerous similar events using the name "Oktoberfest" in Germany and around the world, many of which were founded by German immigrants or their descendants.
Oktoberfest () is the world's largest Volksfest (beer festival and travelling funfair). Held annually in Munich, Bavaria, Germany, it is a 16- to 18-day folk festival running from mid or late September to the first weekend in October, with more than six million people from around the world attending the event every year. Locally, it is often called the Wiesn, after the colloquial name for the fairgrounds, Theresa's meadows ("Theresienwiese"). The Oktoberfest is an important part of Bavarian culture, having been held since the year 1810. Other cities across the world also hold Oktoberfest celebrations that are modeled after the original Munich event.
"September and October, Theresienwiese": The largest beer festival in the world, Munich's Oktoberfest runs for 16–18 days from the end of September through early October. Oktoberfest is a celebration of the wedding of Bavarian Crown Prince Ludwig to Princess Therese of Saxony-Hildburghausen which took place on October 12, 1810. In the last 200 years the festival has grown to span 85 acres and now welcomes over 6 million visitors every year. There are 14 beer tents which together can seat 119,000 attendees at a time, and serve beer from the six major breweries of Munich: Augustiner, Hacker-Pschorr, Löwenbräu, Paulaner, Spaten and Staatliches Hofbräuhaus. Over 7 million liters of beer are consumed at each Oktoberfest. There are also over 100 rides ranging from bumper cars to full-sized roller coasters, as well as the more traditional Ferris wheels and swings. Food can be bought in each tent, as well as at various stalls throughout the fairgrounds. Oktoberfest hosts 144 caterers and employees 13,000 people.
The Oktoberfest of Blumenau was created in 1984, after a big flood of the Itajaí-Açu river, with the objective of recuperating the city's economy and raising the morale of its inhabitants. Even before that, owners of industries and commercial buildings in the city were already planning to start a festival like the original fromm Munich, but the flood was an important event that set the festival in motion. Since its first edition it has been a success, and today it has an attendance of about than 700,000/year. The event features folk dance ("Tanzgruppen)", shooting matches ("Schützenvereine"), German singing, folk costume and german cuisine. "Fritz" and "Frida" are the typical German characters. The ""Vovó e Vovô Chopão"" (Grandma and Grandpa "Chopão", "Big Beer") are the official symbolic characters of the event.
On the occasion of the 200th anniversary in 2010 a so-called "Historisches Oktoberfest" (Historical Oktoberfest) was designed on the site of the Central Agricultural Festival at the south end of the "Theresienwiese". It opened one day before the official Oktoberfest with the traditional keg tapping by the Lord Mayor.
Maifest, similar to Oktoberfest, has now become a popular celebration throughout the world. It has been celebrated in Cincinnati, Ohio, United States since 1873.
Oktoberfest Zinzinnati is an annual weekend festival in the city of Cincinnati, Ohio. Based on the original German Oktoberfest, it is billed as the largest Oktoberfest celebration in the United States. First held in 1976, it attracts an estimated 500,000 visitors every year in late September. It is held along six blocks of Downtown Cincinnati. As of 2016, Oktoberfest is held on 3rd Street to clear room for Cincinnati Streetcar operations.
Oktoberfest is an outdoor beer festival held during a 16-day period running from late September to the first weekend in October, celebrating beer in Munich, Germany.
